item.title: Evaluation and Clear Thinking
item.description: Sometimes I get stuck on making decisions, coming to terms with an idea or choice, or just plain seeing through the muck.

item.title: Self-Reliant Tech
item.description: On craftsmanship, curiosity, and the love of know-how.

item.title: Principles and Beliefs
item.description: A dude‘s gotta have a code, y’know?

item.title: Skulls and Spooky Stuff
item.description: I have always liked spooky stuff, and it’s an inspiration for a lot of my art.

item.title: Accessibility Audit Guide
item.description: What to look for when auditing a site or app for accessibility issues.

item.title: Collaborating
item.description: What does good collaboration look like from each discipline’s perspective?

item.title: Crazy 8s
item.description: An exercise in idea generation.

item.title: Design Presentations
item.description: On presenting design work and soliciting feedback.

item.title: Ethnographic Interviews
item.description: Why interviewing people in their environment is crucial. Includes a guide for conducting them.

item.title: Journey Map
item.description: An exercise to understand the person’s journey through a service.

item.title: Quick Start Guide
item.description: A quick checklist to make sure designers have what they need to get going at the start of a project.

item.title: User Interviews & Tests
item.description: Why we observe users in their environment, the benefits, and a script for getting started.

item.title: User Recruiting Script
item.description: A script that you can send to people you want to interview for your research.

item.title: User Research Plan
item.description: A guide for planning your research that will convince your stakeholders that the time investment is worth it.

item.title: User Research Tools
item.description: A collection of tools that’ll help you along your way in user research.

item.title: How To Give Effective Feedback Remotely (Smashing Magazine)
item.description: I wrote about how to give good feedback to other designers and why it’s worth the effort.

item.title: What we look for in a product designer’s portfolio
item.description: When I ran design at a consultancy, here’s what I looked for in a designer’s portfolio.

item.title: Deep Work, Quarantine Edition
item.description: Something I deeply believe is that if you’re able to have focused time to work, you’re going to be able to go further, faster, and deeper than those who don’t.

item.title: We Need a Code of Ethics.
item.description: Tech has got to get a code of ethics, ffs.

item.title: End of Day ceremonies, the key to sleeping better and staying focused during quarantine
item.description: How to empty your brain at the end of the day so you’re able to be present in your non-work life.

item.title: How using Cranky Conclusions makes tough conversations easier
item.description: Ever needed to tell a teammate something tough but fear they’ll get too defensive? Here’s one way that’s proven to work.

item.title: The Prime Directive and the limits of assuming positive intent
item.description: I tackled the notion of assuming positive intent when it comes to conflict. It isn’t as good an idea as you might think.

item.title: How video games taught me to be better at conflict
item.description: An exploration of pattern-based video games and and the correlation to conflict at work.

item.title: Black Mirror brainstorms — a product design exercise (UX Collective)
item.description: I want to have more ethical products. I feel like we all do. Sometimes, though, we don’t consider how this amazing thing we’re working on might have some unintended and negative consequences.

item.title: What I learned making my first VR app (Prototypr)
item.description: I got to learn about designing for VR, and boy are the principles different there.

item.title: I turned off my push notifications and I’ve never been happier
item.description: One of many things I tried to reclaim my sanity from push notification hell.

item.title: Notifications stress me out. How I cut them down to improve my well-being (CBC Radio)
item.description: I was interviewed by CBC to discuss push notificaitons and the stress they cause.

item.title: Effective Animation
item.description: Over the years, animation evolved from a nice-to-have concept to a core feature. Now, the best companies use animation to inform, delight, and reward the people using their products. Let’s talk about how animation helps and how to use it in our work.

item.title: Push Notifications, the good, the bad, and the wtf could u not (UX Collective)
item.description: Why you should give people more control over the notifications they receive from you.

item.title: Giving Your Product A Soul (Smashing Magazine)
item.description: I wrote about why it’s important that the products we make have a little personality. Not delight, but soul.

item.title: One idea that could curb harassment on social media
item.description: I’ve always been thinking about how to reduce harassment and annoyance on the web, here are some early thoughts.

item.title: Tips for perfect readability with a little help from The Big Lebowski
item.description: Written shortly after the release of my first typeface, Uptown Sans. I ended up giving a talk on this at GIANTConf in Charleston, SC.

item.title: Why I pulled a HULK SMASH on my social media presence
item.description: I’ve had this feeling that the amount of brainspace that social media occupied was out of balance for me.

item.title: My week with Soylent 1.4, or “Oh god I want a burger”
item.description: I tried Soylent. I did not love it.

item.title: Requiem for a side project, quitting AwesomeGIFs
item.description: I ran a site called AwesomeGIFs, and eventually left it. RIP.

item.title: Prototyping iOS And Android Apps With Sketch (Smashing Magazine)
item.description: I designed a lot of mobile apps in the 2010s, here’s how I did it with Sketch.

item.title: Spock, Kirk, and the ideal designer/engineer relationship
item.description: I’ve long been a fan of collaboration between design and engineering.

item.title: In which a nerd changes almost every part of his life to be better designer
item.description: Early writing on becoming a better designer.

item.title: How To Make An Effective Style Guide With Adobe Fireworks (Smashing Magazine)
item.description: Style guides and Adobe Fireworks. This article is old, but one of my first ever published.

item.title: iOS Grid System, A Free Extension For Adobe Fireworks (Smashing Magazine)
item.description: One of my first ever published articles, extolling my love for grids.

item.title: My real problem with in-app rating modules
item.description: Early work on in-app rating modules and how I made them better. This was before Apple launched their own in-app rating system.

item.title: How smartphones could improve texting emergency services
item.description: Early writing on how someone texting with emergency services would be beneficial with ideas on how it might work.

item.title: Spirit Acid
item.description: Found imagery collage, hand-cut type.

item.title: Azibo
item.description: Designing a cohesive, valuable experience for property owners.

item.title: Spirit Photography [Series]
item.description: Mixed media collage focusing on spirit photography, an early 1900s pseudoscientific phenomenon.

item.title: Candy
item.description: Launching and iterating on a two-sided NFT marketplace for Major League Baseball.

item.title: Holograph [Series]
item.description: A series that revisited some older works and tried seeing them in a new light.

item.title: iPod Restorations [Series]
item.description: I restore old tech, and have a huge love of iPods.

item.title: Aperture Health
item.description: Modernizing a 20 (!) year old medical credentialing system.

item.title: Burn [Series]
item.description: What if we burned mantras into our brains?

item.title: Skulls [Series-000]
item.description: Sometimes I fix watches. Sometimes they explode on me. These are experiments with 1950s timepieces that didn’t get fixed. I integrated its parts into two skulls. A memento mori.

item.title: Skulls [Series-001]
item.description: Experiment in applying an iron oxide coating to a resin skull, then letting it rust. I also rusted the nails in a solution of vinegar and hydrogen peroxide.

item.title: Skulls [Series-002]
item.description: Chrome, shiny, and metallic.

item.title: Skulls [Series-003]
item.description: Experiment with unicorn skeleton and color-sensitive paint.

item.title: Skulls [Series-004]
item.description: Integrating a blackout painted skull with a vintage 1900s typewriter

item.title: EVgo
item.description: Designing a cross-platform mobile app and design system for EV charging.

item.title: Assembled Financial
item.description: Designing a fintech startup focused on the CARES Act from scratch.

item.title: New York Collage
item.description: Mixed media collage for Elementary, My Dears Podcast

item.title: Pandemic [Series]
item.description: What do you do when you’re stuck inside and the world crashing down around you? Make art. This isn’t happy stuff.

item.title: CoreLogic Store
item.description: Redesigning an industry leader’s store for custom real estate reports.

item.title: US Space Force
item.description: Designing a workflow and interface to help shoot lasers into space.

item.title: an endless echo
item.description: Typographic experiment in visualizing echoes.

item.title: De-enlightenment [Series]
item.description: Disillusionment visualized.

item.title: delete me
item.description: Hand-set typography, mixed media collage.

item.title: Helvetica Blanc Collab
item.description: Spooky creatures and moody landscapes.

item.title: i’m afraid of americans
item.description: Who isn’t?

item.title: Is everything speeding up
item.description: Pixel ruined digital collage.

item.title: Little Fears [Series]
item.description: A series dedicated to automatic writing and textural experiments.

item.title: Little Weirdos [Series]
item.description: I have no justification for any of this, except that it was weird and fun.

item.title: Mementos Mori [Series]
item.description: A combination of something lively and organic with something … not lively.

item.title: Our Light
item.description: Whose light is it anyway?

item.title: Our New Home
item.description: What is home?

item.title: Processing [Series]
item.description: Made with processing.js, among other things.

item.title: Red Tape [Series]
item.description: Experiments with light, scanners, and tape.

item.title: Softly we rush onward
item.description: Craft night exploration.

item.title: The Black Tape [Series]
item.description: Transparency paper, cutouts, tape, ruined scans.

item.title: Thoughts and Prayers [Series]
item.description: Stop it, do something.

item.title: Video [Series]
item.description: Some video experiments I did with apps on my phone, weird TVs, and other found footage.

item.title: When It’s Over [Series]
item.description: Made with processing.js, Photoshop, and other pixel ruiners.

item.title: Where Is Home
item.description: After a Bloc Party song of the same name.

item.title: Family Dollar
item.description: Designing an iOS and Android app help customers save money.

item.title: Atrium Health
item.description: Designing an iOS and Android app to help patients receive the best care.

item.title: American City Business Journals
item.description: Designing an iOS app and responsive website for a large news publisher.

item.description: Hand-set wood type poster.

Details # Details shortcode is a helper for details html5 element. It is going to replace expand shortcode. Example # {{< details "Title" [open] >}} ## Markdown content Lorem markdownum insigne... {{< /details >}} {{< details title="Title" open=true >}} ## Markdown content Lorem markdownum insigne... {{< /details >}} Title Markdown content # Lorem markdownum insigne…

Expand # Expand shortcode can help to decrease clutter on screen by hiding part of text. Expand content by clicking on it. KaTeX # KaTeX shortcode let you render math typesetting in markdown document. See KaTeX Example # {{</* katex [display] [class="text-center"] */>}} f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty\hat f(\xi)\,e^{2 \pi i \xi x}\,d\xi {{</* /katex */>}} \[f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty\hat f(\xi)\,e^{2 \pi i \xi x}\,d\xi\] Display Mode Example # Here is some inline example: \(\pi(x)\) , rendered in the same line. And below is display example, having display: block \[f(x) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty\hat f(\xi)\,e^{2 \pi i \xi x}\,d\xi\] Text continues here.

Mermaid Chart # MermaidJS is library for generating svg charts and diagrams from text. Override Mermaid Initialization Config To override the initialization config for Mermaid, create a mermaid.json file in your assets folder! Example # {{</* mermaid [class="text-center"]*/>}} stateDiagram-v2 State1: The state with a note note right of State1 Important information! You can write notes. end note State1 --> State2 note left of State2 : This is the note to the left.

item.title: About
item.description: Basquiat How’s this built? # I use Hugo, a static site generator. It’s working with Go, markdown, and powered by GitHub pages. There’s no fancy CMS, no loads of animations. In the future, I’ll be focusing on making it even easier and greener to load, adding image dithering and hopefully attempting to most entirely to green, solar-powered hosting. What’s the idea? # This site is inspired by the concept of digital gardening.

item.title: Appearances and Mentions
item.description: Places I’ve spoken at or were mentioned by. Speaking # Design @ Scale Agile 2022 FiTC O’Reilly Media Online 2019 Rad Summit 2019 Meetups Selected Media #

item.title: Coaching & Consulting
item.description: I offer coaching engagements through my company, Nice Weather, and consulting engagements. Consulting # I help my clients build new capabilities, products, and teams. I also help them do it in a way that’s unique to their culture, not just giving them a process to follow and taking their money. If you’d like to work together, visit my portfolio to see some recent examples of my work. Coaching # I created a coaching company in 2022 because I really wanted to focus on putting more kindness and thoughtfulness into the leadership process.

item.title: Consulting
item.description: I help my clients build new capabilities, products, and teams. I also help them do it in a way that’s unique to their culture, not just giving them a process to follow and taking their money. If you’d like to work together, visit my portfolio to see some recent examples of my work.

item.title: Cosmata
item.description: Cosmata is geometric sans serif family of 10 fonts suitable for both display and reading use. Inspired by Futura, Cosmata developed its own complex, unique life. Buy it at MyFonts To that end, I’ve included alternate letterforms for a finely-tailored typographic experience. The rhythm, kerning, and spacing have been lovingly crafted for an elegant reading experience. I’m excited to share this release with you and hope you enjoy using it as much as I did creating it.

item.title: Design Process
item.description: “Wait a minute,” you say to yourself, “Why do you, a design leader, need to spell out a design process? Doesn’t your team do that work?” Sure, the team might do it, but it’s important to spell out out for two reasons: I wouldn’t ask my team to do anything I wouldn’t do myself. And depending on the situation, I may actually do it myself. Practice, after all, is how you stay sharp and relevant.

item.title: Interstellar Spray Paint Textures
item.description: Buy it at Creative Market Add a little cosmic action to your next design project with these 10 hand-made spray paint textures. They’re huge, grayscale webps that you can drop into any project, mask, and color in no time. This also includes smaller versions of these should you need a smaller file. Whether you want to add an ethereal feel to your project or some grit, these textures can handle both.

item.title: Joshua Mauldin
item.description: Photo by Sarah DeShields Multidisciplinary artist, designer, human who cares about kindness and animals. Biography # I’m not like other design leaders. My ideal day isn’t sitting in strategy meetings all day, managing managers. Instead, I find joy in working at both the strategic tactical level. Some call it a player-coach, I call it my happy place. Since starting my career, I’ve built high-performing, deeply collaborative design teams from scratch and designed 5-star mobile apps.

item.title: Media
item.description: I watch and read a lot. Here’s some of it. Books Incoming # Salem’s Lot Dark Delicacies Vol 1 Notes on Complexity Listening to the music machines make Outrage Machine Pet Semetary 2023 # The Destroyer of Worlds (A Return Lovecraft Country) Little Heaven The Deep The Troop Unbury Carol Dead of Night: A Zombie Novel (Dead of Night Series Book 1) Queen of Teeth The Butcher How minds are changed Chaos machine Mind gut connection Brain energy Pretty Marys All in a Row Boneset & Feathers The Rust Maidens Reluctant Immprtals Old Souls: The Sages and Mystics of Our World Sundial The Paris Apartment Come As You Are Even The Worm Will Turn No Gods for Drowning The Worm and His Kings Your Mind Is a Terrible Thing Echo Hex Malorie: A Bird Box Novel The Living Dead How Minds Change The Chaos Machine Film & TV Incoming # Return to Seoul (2022) 2023 # Oppenheimer The Conjuring 2 Zombieland: Double Tap Crimson Peak The Autopsy of Jane Doe Annabelle Resident Evil: Retribution Lords of Chaos Cargo Black Christmas The Lords of Salem The Silence Smile Candyman The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It Halloween Kills The Menu Evil Dead Rise Scream VI 2022 # Texas Chainsaw Massacre In the Earth Fresh The Power of the Dog The Night House Censor Happy Death Day Saint Maud Mandy Relic Ready or Not The Invitation His House Can You Ever Forgive Me?

item.title: Nice Weather
item.description: I created a coaching company in 2022 because I really wanted to focus on putting more kindness and thoughtfulness into the leadership process. The key idea being that leadership’s future is human-centered. The link below will tell you more. Nice Weather - Developing Human-Centered Leaders

item.title: Personal Sphere
item.description: Here you’ll find a catalog of my artwork and creative endeavors, my personal blog, and other miscellaneous things I’ve enjoyed. Visual Art # A selection of works. Mixed media collage, glitch art, music industry work, skulls (not real ones!), and tinkering with old tech. Lots of darker themes exploring identity, loneliness, memento moris. Journal # I’m intentionally not calling this a blog, as that comes with expectations of constant updates.

item.title: Philosophy of Design
item.description: The most effective process is one that’s resilient and adaptable. That means being principle-driven and not process-driven. Here’s why: each project, problem, and team are unique. Each person’s insight and experience are, too. Following principles instead of a rigorous process lets us honor that uniqueness to deliver truly wonderful results. Not only that, we can move quickly and with intention to deliver great software. You can read how it looks in practice, too.

item.title: Product Design & Development
item.description: Examples of work, guides and resources for leaders and those who aspire to be. Work Portfolio Guides & Resources See also # Docs We Need to Talk Workshops & Speaking

item.title: Professional Sphere
item.description: Here you’ll find all things related to work. Guides, research, thoughts, PDFs, etc. Portfolio # A selection of work from the last 15+ years. Docs # A collection of things I’ve written, plus guides for leaders, workshop facilitators, and other curious people. Design Philosophy # The why behind how I do it. Design Process # How I do what I do. We Need to Talk, a Book # I’m writing a book for Rosenfeld Media.

item.title: Research& Prototypes& Pixels&Code Shirt
item.description: Purchase link (sold out) This is a modern take on the classic Beatles shirt, focused on the design process. I originally designed this for BlendConf, a lovely conference in Charlotte (RIP). Each shirt will be unique, as the gradients have to be made by hand. This shirt is printed on an ultra-soft, vintage black cotton shirt. There are also neat printing processes at work, notably something called split fountain gradients.

item.title: Tools and Items for Sale
item.description: Here are products that I offer. They range from books to typefaces to design supplies. Cosmata # A beatufiful geometric sans serif family. Uptown Sans # My first typeface! Research& Prototypes& Pixels&Code Shirt # Known as “The Process Shirt.” Interstellar Spray Paint Textures # Textures for Photoshop. See also # We Need to Talk

item.title: Uptown Sans
item.description: About Uptown Sans What if Jim Flora (a record cover designer from the 50s), Saul Bass, and Eric Carle got together for tacos and made a typeface? That’s the vibe of Uptown Sans. It’s a little weird, a little loud, and full of energy. It’s sure to help you express yourself in just the right way. Buy it at Fontspring Cool, so what’s it good for? Uptown Sans is best used large.

item.title: We Need to Talk
item.description: My forthcoming book for Rosenfeld Media, due out in 2023. It’s about how to have hard conversations with anyone at work. Too few teams truly embrace healthy conflict—the secret to building great products—so I conduct workshops that teach you how to leverage it with practical, equitable, non-prescriptive methods to craft the best possible version of your product, your team, and even yourself. My workshops give you tools you can use immediately in your next tough conversation.

item.title: Workshops & Speaking
item.description: I offer half and full-day workshops that help teams unlock the secret to building great products: embracing healthy conflict and building psychological safety. We’ll work together to craft plans tailored to your team’s needs. Since beginning my speaking career, I’ve: Talked with web3 engineers at ETHDenver on why they should care about design Given a masterclass at Rosenfeld’s Design at Scale Conference to product managers and designers on how and why to have hard conversations Showed fintech startups on how to unlock their creative thinking with a little more mindfulness and deep focus I care deeply about bringing more mindfulness to your craft and more humanity to your relationships at every level—I’m prepared to show you how that directly benefits your company, too.
